questions.text: A 2 years old child present with sudden onset of breathing difficulty while playing. There are no prior history of any breathing disorder. CXR shows hyperinflation of right lung with normal left lung. Which of the following statement is true regarding this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Focal area of decrease air entry confirms the diagnosis of foreign body

options.label: C
options.text: In complete obstruction, ball valve mechanism leads to such condition

options.label: D
options.text: Prefer way of removing is flexible bronchoscopy

questions.correct_answer: B. Focal area of decrease air entry confirms the diagnosis of foreign body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Focal area of decrease air entry confirms the diagnosis of foreign body Hyperinflation of the right lung with normal left lung in a 2 year old child indicated foreign body in the right bronchus. Option B: For such cases removal of foreign body should be done with rigid bronchoscopy instead of flexible bronchoscopy to ensure avoidance of complications. The child's sudden onset of breathing difficulty while playing and the findings on the chest X-ray ( hyperinflation of the right lung with normal left lung) suggest a possible foreign body aspiration . When a foreign body obstructs the airway, it can cause hyperinflation of the affected lung due to trapped air. This results in decreased air entry to the affected lung, leading to a focal area of decreased air entry on examination.

Highyeild:

Children between the ages of 1 and 4 are prone to aspirating small objects into their air passages. Foreign body aspiration can lead to significant respiratory morbidity, including recurrent wheezing, coughing, and pneumonia. Immediate responses to foreign body aspiration include choking, gagging, coughing, or localized wheezing. After the initial episode, symptoms may improve temporarily and the incident may be forgotten. The severity and course of illness depend on the nature, size, extent, and site of the foreign body obstruction. Organic or vegetable foreign bodies can swell up and cause more symptoms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C: Complete obstruction of bronchus can cause hyperinflated lung due to stop valve effect and not by ball valve effect. Option A and D: The term "croup" colloquially describes both laryngotracheobronchitis and laryngotracheitis and is a very common cause of a cough, stridor, and hoarseness in children with a fever. Croup is most often a viral infection that affects the subglottic airway, commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus. Croup occurs more commonly in boys than in girls. It frequently occurs in children aged 6 months to 6 years old. One to three days of rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and fever usually precedes croup. Typical symptoms of croup include a barky or a seal-like cough, hoarse voice, and high pitched inspiratory stridor that parents may incorrectly describe as “wheezing.” Inhalation of the virus causing croup first infects the nasal and pharyngeal mucosal epithelia, then spreads to the subglottic space. For children 8 years and younger, the subglottic space is the most narrow part of the airway. The cricoid cartilage forms a complete cartilaginous ring that is non expanding. This inability of the cricoid to expand leads to a significant narrowing of the subglottic region secondary to the inflamed mucosa. When the child cries or becomes agitated, further dynamic obstruction can occur at and below the cartilaginous ring. These factors lead to the common high-pitched stridor heard at rest and when the patient becomes agitated. Extension into the bronchi, as occurs with laryngotracheobronchitis, can lead to wheezing, crackles, air trapping, and increased tachypnea; a clinical picture that can be confused with acute asthma.

Extraedge:

Partial obstruction can lead to a ball valve effect, resulting in localized hyperinflation. Clinical signs may include hyperresonance, diminished vocal resonance, and poor air entry. It can be challenging to elicit hyperresonance in small children. A localized area of poor air entry in a child with chronic respiratory illness should raise suspicion of a foreign body. Complete obstruction and surrounding inflammation can cause distal atelectasis and suppuration of the surrounding lung tissue. Loss of bronchial elasticity can result in segmental dilatation and eventual development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 4 month old infant which was born to a HIV positive mother presented with diarrhea. What is the next step of investigation ? PEDIATRICS
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HIV PCR HIV PCR should be done in infants of HIV infected mother within first 48 hours to establish diagnosis and plan management.

Highyeild:

Infants born to HIV-infected mothers test positive for HIV antibodies at birth due to passive transfer from the mother. Antibody tests should not be used to diagnose HIV in infants. Most uninfected infants lose maternal antibodies between 6 and 18 months of age. Positive IgG antibody tests cannot definitively diagnose HIV in infants under 24 months. IgA or IgM anti-HIV assays are not reliable for diagnosis. HIV PCR is the next step of investigation in a 4-month-old infant with diarrhea. Viral diagnostic assays like HIV DNA or RNA PCR are useful for diagnosing HIV infection in young infants.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - HIV antibody detection in early infancy can be from maternal antibodies. Antibody detection should be done at 1-2 months and then 4-6 months of age to establish immune status of the infant. Option C - Post-exposure prophylaxis ART is usually given to infants of HIV infected mothers. No role in detection of causative organism. Option D - HIV should be the first organism to be ruled out in infants of HIV infected mothers.

Extraedge:

Virologic testing should be done within the first 12-24 hours of life for high-risk infants. Additional virologic testing should be performed at specific intervals for monitoring. Positive virologic assay results should be confirmed with repeat testing. Multiple negative virologic tests can presumptively exclude HIV infection. HIV antibody testing may be considered at 12-18 months of age in high-risk infants or those infected with non-subtype B viruses.

questions.text: A 11 yr old patient with fever, poly arthritis had history of sore throat 45 days ago. Investigations showed throat swab positive for streptococcus. Raised ESR. However on echo there was no valvular disease and no features of Carditis. No past history of rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis recommended is benzathine penicillin injection 600000 units every 3 weeks for? PEDIATRICS

options.label: A
options.text: 5 yrs or upto 18 yrs of age whichever is later

options.label: B
options.text: 10 yrs or upto 25 yrs of age whichever is later

questions.correct_answer: A. 5 yrs or upto 18 yrs of age whichever is later
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 yrs or upto 18 yrs of age whichever is later Recommended dose for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease post streptococcal infections is 5 yrs or upto 18 yrs of age whichever is later. ALSO NOTE: DOSAGE OF BENZATHINE PENICILLIN FOR OTHER DISEASES: PRIMARY SYPHILIS: Single dose (2.4 Million Units) CVS SYPHILIS: 3 shots weekly GABHS infection causing renal involvement: Single dose IM Duration of Prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin) No carditis 5 years; till 18 years of age Mild to moderate carditis 10 years; till 25years of age Severe carditis Lifelong; till 40 years of age

Highyeild:

Antibiotic therapy for GAS ( Group A Streptococcus ) pharyngitis is important to prevent acute rheumatic fever, shorten the clinical course, reduce transmission, and prevent complications. Penicillin or amoxicillin is the drug of choice for treating pharyngeal infections and suppurative complications. Oral penicillin V is recommended, taken for a full 10-day course, even if there is improvement within a few days. Benzathine penicillin G is an alternative for parenteral therapy with a single intramuscular injection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - 10 yrs or upto 25 yrs of age whichever is later - for patient with mild to moderate carditis. Option C - Single Dose - not recommended Option D - Life Long - in severe carditis.

questions.text: Mother was worried that her child did not pass urine on post-natal day 1, what advice will you give?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue Breastfeeding and Observe The Nelson's textbook as well as latest clinical practice guidelines state that passage of urine for the first time after birth should occur within 48 hrs delivery; While meconium passage should be expected within 24 hrs of delivery in a normal neonate. Here since the neonate is only one day old, it can still be considered normal and is probably due to improper feeding practice thus causing dehydration. There is also a possibility that occurrence of urination wasn't noticed due to meconium passage. Thus it is recommended that breastfeeding should be continued in a proper manner for one more day.

Highyeild:

It is normal for a newborn to have delayed passage of urine in the first 24 hours after birth. Breastfeeding is the recommended feeding method for newborns, and it provides adequate hydration. As long as the baby is breastfeeding well and shows no signs of distress, it is generally unnecessary to intervene or start additional feeding methods. Close observation should be maintained to ensure proper hydration and monitor the baby's overall well-being.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C and D - Starting IV fluids or admitting the patient with aggressive investigations at this point is not necessary. Option A - Start Formula Milk - not recommended in this case.

questions.text: A young child was brought by his mother complaining of multiple episodes of loose stools with drowsiness/ lethargy. Skin pinch was going back very slowly and child was not accepting breast feeds. What is the grade of dehydration?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe Child with drowsiness and lethargy Skin pinch - very slow Not accepting breast feeds. So using the below mentioned table - this looks like a severe case - Option A is the appropriate answer.

Highyeild:

The child presented with multiple episodes of loose stools, drowsiness/lethargy, slow skin pinch return, and refusal of breastfeeds. These symptoms indicate severe dehydration in the child. Severe dehydration is characterized by significant fluid loss. Prompt medical attention and appropriate rehydration therapy are necessary to address the severe dehydration. Severe dehydration can lead to serious complications if not treated promptly.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - incorrect - as dehydration is present visibly , proved by skin pinch test. Option C - Mild - it will be the case where skin pinch is delayed only - the child will be feeding very eagerly. Option D - some dehydration - this has characteristics in between mild and severe dehydration.
